title: Scar House Reservoir Walk Route

images.title: Mick Melvin / Scar House Reservoir
images.caption: Dropping onto Scar House from the Nidderdale way

images.title: Andy Beecroft / Looking towards Scar House Reservoir
images.caption: Looking towards Scar House Reservoir. Photo taken at MR: SE09377776 looking in a SWW direction from the footpath. Note the pretty heather by the footpath

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Choppy water - Scar House Reservoir
images.caption: Choppy water - Scar House Reservoir. A strong wind whips up the waves at the eastern end of Scar House Reservoir. With the air temperature at 0.5 celsius and a 30 knot wind coming straight off the snowfields on Great Whernside, the conditions can best be described as 'bracing'.

images.title: Mark Anderson / Ruined wall above Scar House Reservoir
images.caption: Ruined wall above Scar House Reservoir. The high ground to the south has kept this area in shadow all day, allowing the frost to remain.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Scar House Reservoir
images.caption: Originally constructed for Bradford Corporation, the reservoir came into operation in 1935 following the building of Scar House Dam. Looking across the reservoir towards Little Whernside, which is the most easterly 600m summit in Britain.

images.title: Frank Glover / Scar House Reservoir Plaque
images.caption: This plaque, commemorating the opening of Scar House Reservoir, is set into the eastern parapet of the dam.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Choppy water - Scar House Reservoir
images.caption: Choppy water - Scar House Reservoir. A strong wind whips up the waves at the eastern end of Scar House Reservoir. With the air temperature at 0.5 celsius and a 30 knot wind coming straight off the snowfields on Great Whernside, the conditions can best be described as 'bracing'.

images.title: Mick Melvin / Scar House Reservoir Nidderdale
images.caption: Scar House Reservoir Nidderdale

description: This circular walk takes you around Scar House Reservoir to Angram Reservoir in Nidderdale. The reservoir has a well surfaced footpath running around the perimeter and a car park at the eastern end. It runs for nearly 4 miles and is fairly flat so will suit most abilities. The surrounding countryside is beautiful with views of the Yorkshire Hills and the River Nidd. You can easily extend your walk by picking up the Nidderdale Way and heading along the river. Following the trail south will take you to Middlesmoor where you can visit the wonderful How Stean Gorge .
